snippet: If Chinese officials hoped the trial of Bo Xilai’s wife would show off a more transparent legal system, they are likely to be disappointed.
abstract: Gu Kailai, the wife of the ousted Chinese party leader Bo Xilai, is said to have confessed to the murder of the British businessman, Neil Heywood, after a neatly packaged murder trial that lasted less than seven hours; prosecutors claim she killed him over worries that he might harm her only child; Gu and her accomplice, Zhang Xiaojun, were deprived of their own legal counsel and forced to accept a government-appointed lawyer; no defense witnesses were produced and the defendants’ lawyers had no chance to review the prosecution’s evidence.

byline.contributor: Mia Li, Patrick Zuo and Shi Da contributed research from Beijing. John F. Burns contributed reporting from London.

lead_paragraph: If Chinese officials hoped the trial of Bo Xilai’s wife would show off a more transparent legal system, they are likely to be disappointed.

headline.seo: Murder Trial of Chinese Official’s Wife Begins and Concludes
headline.main: Fast-Paced Trial in China Murder Leaves Shadows
